newsitem.title: JAPAN: Chrysler launches Voyager minivan in Japan.
newsitem.headline: Chrysler launches Voyager minivan in Japan.

text.p: Chrysler Corp will this Saturday begin selling a new Voyager minivan specifically designed to compete in the Japanese market, the U.S. automaker said on Wednesday.
Left-hand-drive Voyagers are already sold in Japan by some independent smaller importer-dealers.

Prices for the new minivans will range from 3.19 million yen ($25,300) to 3.82 million yen ($30,300), Chrysler Japan Sales Ltd Chairman Keisuke Egashira told a news conference previewing the new model.
"We belive we have succeeded in pricing Voyager competitively for this market and versus other premium vehicles available to Japanese consumers," Egashira said.
He declined to reveal a sales target for the new vehicles.
"We have less experience on marketing this segment model in Japan so it is hard to set sales target," Egashira said.
He also said it was not necessarily true that Japan's auto market is closed to foreign imports, noting a slow but steady increase in imports in recent years.

"Carmakers which make cars which meet consumers' demands will win. Good products and a good sales network are the necessary elements for boosting sales in Japan. It is not up to the U.S. and Japanese governments," he said.
Japanese sales of Chrysler cars, including the Cherokee sport-utility vehicle, rose 6.6 percent in 1996 from a year earlier to 14,504 units.
